type.title: Common
type.explanation: These are everyday names for just about any situation.  Some sound more impressive than others, but they all come across as ordinary names that anyone could bear.  Because of the vast number of combinations possible with names, these are by no means intended to represent the “most” common names.

romanisations.meaning: Guoqing: National Day holiday in China
Aimin: Care for the common people (usually said of a ruler, official, army, etc.)
Lei: Heap of stones, open and honest

type.title: Uncommon
type.explanation: These names feature uncommon or archaic characters that aren’t often seen.  Generally speaking, these names sound impressive and unique, and are the type that would stand out or be easy to recall.

romanisations.meaning: Changqing: An archaic word for butterfly
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch

type.title: Dark
type.explanation: These are names that generally come across as either sounding evil, dangerous, violent, or negative in some way.  Generally, they are perfect for villainous characters, or at least, characters who are not righteous heroes.  They are best paired with the Dark surnames above, although that is not a hard and fast rule.

romanisations.meaning: Chou: Enemy, foe, hate, loathe, grudge
Shang: Die in war, die young
Sha: Brake, stop (This character is pronounced the same and resembles the character for “kill” 殺/杀)
Mochou: This is the given name of a famous wuxia villainess, Li Mouchou
Mo: Do not, there is none who
Yue: Amputate the feet as punishment
Ling: The sound of flowing water

type.title: Righteous
type.explanation: These are names that sound upright, righteous, and good.  They are the type of names you would expect to be borne by heroic people who espouse justice and fight for the commoners.

romanisations.meaning: Peng: The Peng, a mythological bird sometimes translated as “roc”
Wei: Did not, have not, eighth Earthly branch

type.title: Dramatic
type.explanation: These are names which sound emotional, melancholic, or dramatic in some way.  They are best paired with the Dramatic surnames above, although that is not a hard and fast rule.

romanisations.meaning: Zhuang: To dress up, to adorn, makeup
Zhen: Pillow, rest one’s head in sleep
Changqing: A rare word for butterfly
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch
Xi: No meaning, this character is an exclamatory particle

type.title: Masculine
type.explanation: These names all sound masculine in nature.

romanisations.meaning: Qiankun: Heaven and earth, Yin and Yang, the universe, the cosmos
Qian: Heaven, male, Yang-related, one of the eight trigrams
Kun: Earth, feminine, female, Yin-related, one of the eight trigrams

type.title: Feminine
type.explanation: These names all sound feminine in nature.

romanisations.meaning: Ziwei: Crape myrtle (a tree that usually has purplish flowers)

type.title: Gender-Neutral
type.explanation: These are names which are not immediately identifiable as being either masculine or feminine.

romanisations.meaning: Qiming: Classical Chinese name for planet Venus
Chen: Celestial bodies, fifth Earthly branch
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch

type.title: Artisan
type.explanation: For the most part, these are just ordinary names that you would expect a common person to have.  Being prepared for Artisans in mind, many have a fanciful, creative feeling to them.

romanisations.meaning: Yang: Positive, sun, hot, masculine (from Yin and Yang)
Chen: Celestial bodies, fifth Earthly branch

type.title: Assassin
type.explanation: These names are perfect for hardened killers.  Most sound dramatic or dangerous.

romanisations.meaning: Jing: Chaste tree (a type of tree), thorns, brambles
Yao: Want, ask for, demand, request
Wuxin: Without thought, the mind free from illusion, mindless
Luocha: Raksha, rakshasa (demons that devour men)
Sha: Brake, stop (When used alone, this character is pronounced the same and resembles the character for “kill” 殺/杀)

type.title: Bandit
type.explanation: Most of these names sound like they would belong to common, rough-and-tumble individuals who have fallen into a life of crime.

type.title: Beggar
type.explanation: Most of these names are humble and perhaps even somewhat shameful.

romanisations.meaning: Sheng: Remain, be left, have as a remainder
Zi: Child, son, first Earthly branch

type.title: Constable
type.explanation: For the most part, these are names for ordinary people, but emphasise justice and righteousness, qualities that upstanding constables would espouse.

type.title: Dedicated Martial Practitioner
type.explanation: These names generally feature aspects that cause one to think of martial arts or combat.

romanisations.meaning: Sanfeng: The given name of Zhan Sanfeng, legendary real-life Daoist who is credited with inventing Taichi
Zongyuan: The given name of Liu Zongyuan, a Tang Dynasty poet
Zong: School, sect, purpose, model, ancestor
Yewen: The surname and given name of Ip Man, Cantonese martial artist and teacher of Bruce Lee
Er: Child, son, or a sound word

type.title: Detective
type.explanation: These names conjure the image of an intelligent, free-thinking person.

type.title: Doctor
type.explanation: These names conjure a sensation of benevolence, thoughtfulness, and humanity.

romanisations.meaning: Huatuo: Hua Tuo was a famous doctor during the Han Dynasty
Tuo: To carry on the back
Zhen: Treasure, rare, precious thing, gem
Yan: To spread out, develop, amplify

type.title: Entertainer
type.explanation: These are light, creative names that are perfect for everyone from singers, to actors, to courtesans.

romanisations.meaning: Jia: Fine, good, great, pretty, glorious

type.title: Farmer
type.explanation: These are simple, common names that one would expect to see among ordinary people.  Many emphasize an aspect of nature or hard work that typify farmers.

romanisations.meaning: Xi: Like, be fond of, happy, happiness

type.title: Fisher
type.explanation: These are simple, common names that one would expect to see among ordinary people.  Many emphasise an aspect of nature, water, rivers, or the ocean that typify fishers.

romanisations.meaning: Fa: Send out, show, to issue, to develop
Xia: Red clouds, sunset glow, sunrise glow

type.title: Government Official
type.explanation: These are names that sound formal and dignified, perfect for people attached to the imperial bureaucracy.

romanisations.meaning: Wang: Hope, expect, watch, view, gaze
Shu: Relax, smooth away, smooth down
Bi: Green jade, bluish green, blue, jade

type.title: Loyalist
type.explanation: These names are perfect for faithful, focused individuals.

romanisations.meaning: Su Wu: A famous Chinese statesman from the Han Dynasty
Qingfeng: Cool breeze, pure and honest

type.title: Merchant
type.explanation: These names emphasise wealth and profit, making them perfect for business people.

romanisations.meaning: Wanguan: Ten thousand strings of cash, wealthy, millionaire
Fu: To return, to resume, to recover
Xiang: Toward, in the direction of
